div1.p: Lazear is in Germany practicing his German.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 21, 1890
div1.p:
Here we are in Freiburg
eleven miles from the Rhine and on
the border of the Black Forest. We
came down on Monday from Paris to
Bale or Basel in the northern corner
of Switzerland. There I wrote a letter
to you but in the hurry of starting
I left it in it my room at the
hotel I was very much provoked about
it. We left Basel at four in the
afternoon of Tuesday and walked
to Kirchen where we stopped over
night at an inn. It was a regular
old German Gasthaus. After being
shown to our room, it we went
into the public-room where the
assembled company all spoke to us
and we soon entered into conver-
sation, the landlord leading. He
said he could once read English and
he brought out an English grammar
in German. We got a great deal of
practice in German during the
evening talk. The people here always
take off their hats on entering a
tavern and they always greet you
on the road and are very kind
about giving information about
the roads. Yesterday it rained
most of the time and we could
only get as far as Müllheim,
here we got a good nights rest
with a good dil dinner and
breakfast, all for about eighty
cents a piece. This morning we
walked over to Badenweiler a
which is back in the Black Forest
about three miles. There is a
fine ruin there and and some
old Roman baths built in the
second century. It is now a
fashionable watering place with
baths. From there we walked to
Staufen where there is another
ruined castle. These castles are on
the tops of hills and can be seen
for long distances. The valley of
the Rhine is very broad here and
we can see the Vosges mountains
in the distance on the other side.
This afternoon we walked up to
Freiburg which is a very interesting
place with an old cathedral
and a University. Tomorrow we
will go on with our journey
going toward Strasburg, but
we will hardly be able to reach
it in one day. I am not sure
that we can go there although
we shall be very near it as they
are very particular about pass-
ports in Alsace and Lorraigne and
we have none. We will get
to Heidelberg about Monday
and there I hope to find letters as
I directed them to be sent there.
Before leaving Paris I received a
letter from you and Uncle Tom.
both of which I enjoyed very much.
This is a very fine trip that we
are taking the scenery is mag-
nificent, and we are getting
lots of practice in our German
I speak it much better than I
thought I could. I had a long
talk with the land lady at Müllheim
and I understood her very easily
and had no trouble in making her
understand me. I am very sorry
that I did not get my letter off at
Basel as you will not get a
letter by that mail and I like
to send one by every mail,
